subject: Kelly Wallace: Another Tough Day At Virginia Tech
body:

  The Early Show | CBS Evening News | 48 Hours | 60 Minutes | The Saturday Early Show | CBS Sunday Morning | Face The Nation 






April 
      19, 2007
 
Hello, everyone, 
 
It was another tough day here on the campus of Virginia Tech. 
      Students, trying to comprehend what happened in Monday's massacre, now 
      have to face the angry words and disturbing photos of 
      the gunman, Seung-Hui Cho. 
 
On a 
      special edition of The Early Show from 
      Blacksburg, 
      Va., 
      this morning, we had complete coverage of Cho's tirade-filled manifesto, 
      which he sent to NBC News apparently after his first shooting on campus. 
      Sharyn Alfonsi dissected what's 
      inside the manifesto and Harry Smith talked with criminal profiler Pat 
      Brown about what 
      we can learn from Cho's words and whether there were warning signs 
      that were missed. Harry also talked with Cho's former suitemate and a 
      former classmate to get their 
      reaction to Cho's final comments, and whether they had any indication 
      he could end his life by taking so many 
      others.
 
But our focus also remains on the victims — the 32 innocent lives 
      lost on that tragic day and the wounded who are recovering in area 
      hospitals. Harry talked with the friends of Jeremy Herbstritt, one of the 
      students who was killed, and has an incredible interview with one of the 
      survivors, Garrett Evans of Chicago, who 
      remarkably says he 
      feels sorry for the gunman, 
      and forgives him for what he's done. 
 
I had the story-behind-the-story of one photograph which was splashed across front pages around the country and may become the searing image of the tragic 
      events at Virginia Tech. It shows senior Kevin Sterne, who was shot in the 
      leg, being carried to safety. Sterne, an Eagle Scout, managed to save his 
      life by wrapping a cord around his leg to slow the bleeding. I talked to 
      people who know Kevin, including his former Eagle Scout leader, who 
      believes the training he received helped save his 
      life.
 
And it's hard to believe, but tomorrow marks eight years since the Columbine massacre. 
      Russ Mitchell talked to Brook Brown, who was a student there, and Tom 
      Mauser, who lost a son in that tragedy, to find out what they were 
      thinking when the news came from Virginia 
      Tech.
 
There was other news on The Early Show today: Debbye 
      Turner's update on the latest pet food recall; new information 
      about the connection between hormone replacement therapy and breast cancer; and what may be a growing trend, companies taking steps to 
      allow people of faith to practice at work. 
      Debbye Turner had that story, too.
 
Thanks for watching,



Kelly Wallace
